climbs.name: East Ridge
climbs.fa: Arno Springer and Harold Redekop, July 1982

content.description:
Scramble up the steepening east ridge to the first notch. Descend. Climb the intervening pinnacle directly and rappel from it. Continue out of the second notch to the summit. Technical grade is a wild guess.



Unlike other routes on the mountain, this is most easily reached by following the ridge south from Green Mountain which wraps around and becomes the east ridge of Land, although it can also be reached from Middle (South) Ault Lake.

Presumably a full rack including pitons

A serious route with highly variable rock quality ranging from great to gravel. Probably not worth repeating unless you're looking for some serious climbing. Begin from the second ledge and climb three pitches to the highest ledge. Break through steep walls up a left-angling ramp. From the top of the ramp, trend left on great rock for a pitch, then up two more pitches on rock that gradually becomes more ledgy, heathery and gravelly, with few opportunities for pro (full rope length leads with 0 to 1 pro placements). Finish up a rotten red gully (scary) to the summit ridge. Join the NW face route for the last pitch to the summit up slabby rock, a short steeper polished 5.7 step, and then blocky stemming to top out.



See topo

Light rack from finger sized nuts to 3" cam. Knifeblades and RURPS or copperheads might help for pro on the slammed-shut seams and flaring tips pods prevalent along the route

Climb the snow tongue on the northwest face, north of the west ridge. At its top, it may be necessary to climb a pitch of rock (difficulty ranging from 5.4 to 5.7 depending on how much snow is present) along the final section of the north ridge to the summit. Glacial retreat has made the bottom of this climb steeper since the first ascent.



Straight off the glacier left of the west ridge. The lower portion of the snow tongue is the steepest and can melt out in dry years.

Snow protection, a few nuts and cams in the finger size to 2" range useful for the rock pitch.

The exact details of this route are unclear, but it seems likely that it climbs slabby rock on the west side of the north ridge, left of the NW Face route, to gain the ridge crest. 



Climb easiest line off the glacier to reach the low-gradient top of the north ridge. Follow to summit. Difficulty may have increased since the FA as ice has retreated.

Standard rack

Â From the hanging valley, scramble up Sloan's south flanks, eventually climbing a couple of 5.6 pitches ranging from solid and blocky, to loose blocks, to sand and gravel held together by magic. Jordan climbed to below the summit and descended with one party, then returned and climbed the west ridge with another, traversed to his previous high point, and continued to the summit to finish the route.



Reach the hanging valley south of Sloan directly from Hurley River FSR via a bushwack. 

Standard Squamish rack, extra wizard skills for climbing vertical sand

climbs.name: West Ridge
climbs.fa: FRA: Clifford A. Fenner, Thomas Waldon, Tonophorous Pollard, 1949

content.description:
Climb the prominent west ridge, mostly but not entirely on the south flank. Cross over to the north flank several times. Steep and bouldery fourth class climbing, some may require a few short rappels on the way down. 



Ascend glacier on northwest flank to col. Ridge begins from the col.

Spotters can help for a few of the cruxes.

A sharp granite spire south of Mount Sloan. The name honors Bralorne climber Gerben Land, who made the second and third ascents (both solos) of the peak in the late 1950s and 1960, before dying in a climbing accident elsewhere.
